diagnoses.name: Acute Pericarditis

symptoms_any: Sharp, pleuritic chest pain improved by sitting forward
signs_any: Diffuse ST elevation with PR depression (ECG)

initial_tests: CXR (may be normal or show enlarged silhouette if large effusion)
Blood cultures if febrile; TB/autoimmune/other workup as indicated

all_patients_initial: NSAIDs (ibuprofen, indomethacin, high-dose aspirin) for 1–2 weeks with taper
Colchicine for 3 months to reduce recurrence
Glucocorticoids only if refractory or specific indication (autoimmune, uremia, pregnancy)

follow_up: Repeat echo if effusion suspected or symptoms persist

instructions: Report worsening chest pain, dyspnea, or syncope (tamponade)

diagnoses.name: Pericardial Effusion / Tamponade

signs_any: Muffled heart sounds, JVD, hypotension (Beck’s triad)

initial_tests: Echo (effusion size, diastolic chamber collapse, IVC plethora)
CXR (enlarged cardiac silhouette if large effusion)

stable: Treat underlying cause (infection, malignancy, autoimmune, uremia)
Serial echo monitoring if no tamponade physiology
tamponade: Volume resuscitation and pressors as temporizing measure

follow_up: Monitor for recurrence depending on etiology

instructions: Report syncope, hypotension, or worsening dyspnea immediately
follow_up: Cardiology follow-up; oncology/rheum/nephrology if secondary cause

diagnoses.name: Constrictive Pericarditis
initial_tests: Echo (septal bounce, respiratory ventricular interdependence, thickened pericardium)

definitive: Pericardiectomy for symptomatic patients with chronic constriction

follow_up: Monitor for worsening right-sided HF symptoms
Consider referral for surgical pericardiectomy evaluation

instructions: Daily weight, monitor edema and ascites
Adherence to low-sodium diet and diuretics
